column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=The Man Who Died
#Text=I returned from the City about three o’clock on that May afternoon pretty well disgusted with life .
#Text=I had been three months in the Old Country , and was fed up with it .
#Text=If anyone had told me a year ago that I would have been feeling like that I should have laughed at him ; but there was the fact .
#Text=The weather made me liverish , the talk of the ordinary Englishman made me sick .
#Text=I could n’t get enough exercise , and the amusements of London seemed as flat as soda-water that has been standing in the sun .
#Text=“ Richard Hannay , ” I kept telling myself , “ you have got into the wrong ditch , my friend , and you had better climb out . ”
#Text=It made me bite my lips to think of the plans I had been building up those last years in Buluwayo .
#Text=I had got my pile — not one of the big ones , but good enough for me ; and I had figured out all kinds of ways of enjoying myself .

#Text=My father had brought me out from Scotland at the age of six , and I had never been home since ; so England was a sort of Arabian Nights to me , and I counted on stopping there for the rest of my days .
#Text=But from the first I was disappointed with it .
#Text=In about a week I was tired of seeing sights , and in less than a month I had had enough of restaurants and theatres and race-meetings .
#Text=I had no real pal to go about with , which probably explains things .
#Text=Plenty of people invited me to their houses , but they did n’t seem much interested in me .
#Text=They would fling me a question or two about South Africa , and then get on to their own affairs .
#Text=A lot of Imperialist ladies asked me to tea to meet schoolmasters from New Zealand and editors from Vancouver , and that was the dismalest business of all .
#Text=Here was I , thirty-seven years old , sound in wind and limb , with enough money to have a good time , yawning my head off all day .
#Text=I had just about settled to clear out and get back to the veld , for I was the best bored man in the United Kingdom .

#Text=That afternoon I had been worrying my brokers about investments to give my mind something to work on , and on my way home I turned into my club — rather a pot-house , which took in Colonial members .
#Text=I had a long drink , and read the evening papers .
#Text=They were full of the row in the Near East , and there was an article about Karolides , the Greek Premier .
#Text=I rather fancied the chap .
#Text=From all accounts he seemed the one big man in the show ; and he played a straight game too , which was more than could be said for most of them .
#Text=I gathered that they hated him pretty blackly in Berlin and Vienna , but that we were going to stick by him , and one paper said that he was the only barrier between Europe and Armageddon .
#Text=I remember wondering if I could get a job in those parts .
#Text=It struck me that Albania was the sort of place that might keep a man from yawning .
#Text=About six o’clock I went home , dressed , dined at the Café Royal , and turned into a music-hall .
#Text=It was a silly show , all capering women and monkey-faced men , and I did not stay long .
#Text=The night was fine and clear as I walked back to the flat I had hired near Portland Place .
#Text=The crowd surged past me on the pavements , busy and chattering , and I envied the people for having something to do .
#Text=These shop-girls and clerks and dandies and policemen had some interest in life that kept them going .
#Text=I gave half-a-crown to a beggar because I saw him yawn ; he was a fellow-sufferer .
#Text=At Oxford Circus I looked up into the spring sky and I made a vow .
#Text=I would give the Old Country another day to fit me into something ; if nothing happened , I would take the next boat for the Cape .
#Text=My flat was the first floor in a new block behind Langham Place .
#Text=There was a common staircase , with a porter and a liftman at the entrance , but there was no restaurant or anything of that sort , and each flat was quite shut off from the others .
#Text=I hate servants on the premises , so I had a fellow to look after me who came in by the day .
#Text=He arrived before eight o’clock every morning and used to depart at seven , for I never dined at home .
#Text=I was just fitting my key into the door when I noticed a man at my elbow .
#Text=I had not seen him approach , and the sudden appearance made me start .
#Text=He was a slim man , with a short brown beard and small , gimlety blue eyes .
#Text=I recognized him as the occupant of a flat on the top floor , with whom I had passed the time of day on the stairs .
#Text=“ Can I speak to you ? ” he said .
#Text=“ May I come in for a minute ? ”
#Text=He was steadying his voice with an effort , and his hand was pawing my arm .
#Text=I got my door open and motioned him in .
#Text=No sooner was he over the threshold than he made a dash for my back room , where I used to smoke and write my letters .
#Text=Then he bolted back .
